Sira: It's alright.  This chapter on the French Revolution is pretty interesting, but it's a lot to read! What about your day? Did anything interesting happen at work?

Sira: Okay, well, I've been reading about how the storming of the Bastille wasn't actually as significant as many believe, more of a symbolic event than a major turning point in the revolution itself. It was more about the popular uprising and the symbolic power of the Bastille as a prison.  Want to hear more about that, or something else from the chapter?
Dad: yes please tell me more love

Sira: Okay, so another thing I found interesting is that the role of women in the revolution is often overlooked.  Many women were actively involved in the protests and demonstrations, even though they didnâ€™t have the same political rights as men.  They played a crucial role in spreading revolutionary ideas and providing support to the movement.  What do you think about that?
Dad: I think women were crucial in war they war the best support there can be also the amazing women medics that help people actually survive the war

Sira: Absolutely, Dad.  You're right, they were incredibly important in so many ways.  It's interesting how often their contributions are minimized in history books.  Speaking of which, my textbook actually mentions a few specific examples of women who played key roles in providing medical aid during the French Revolution...  It's pretty fascinating stuff.

And I also like Art History; itâ€™s fascinating to see how artistic styles reflect the social and political changes of different eras.  Actually, there's a great connection between the artistic styles of the Neoclassical period and the ideals of the French Revolutionâ€¦.
